Dispute_Type: Nexus to a Convention ground, Adequate state protection
Legal_Issue: Whether the IRB erred in finding no nexus to a Convention ground and adequate state protection
Evidence_Assessment: IRB found fear stemmed from criminality, not a Convention ground; state protection deemed adequate based on evidence
Burden_of_Proof: Applicants must prove persecution based on a Convention ground and inability of state to protect
Legal_Rule: Applicants must demonstrate persecution linked to a Convention ground and lack of state protection
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of threats from corrupt union officials in Mexico
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed due to lack of nexus and sufficient state protection
Review_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to IRB decision
Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature of threats, role of union officials, effectiveness of state response
Legal_Framework: Refugee protection under international and domestic law
Applicant_Challenge: IRB's determination of no nexus and adequate protection
Legal_Rule_Source: Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Resolution_Mechanism: Administrative determination by IRB, followed by judicial review
Legal_Provision: Section of Immigration and Refugee Protection Act relating to refugee claims
Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court
Legal_Provision_Cited: IRPA sections on refugee eligibility and protection
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Persecution by non-state actors without state complicity or inability to protect
Outcome_of_Review: No error found in IRB decision
Governing_Rule: International refugee law, Canadian administrative law
